Package it.unimore.iot.health.api.datamanager.resources

Class PatientResource

java.lang.Object
it.unimore.iot.health.api.datamanager.resources.PatientResource
@Path("/api/iot/inventory/patient") public class PatientResource extends Object
PatientResource class contains a series of methods necessary for the correct management of incoming requests by a client, in accordance with the CRUD manipulation of the patient resource. Therefore, any request sent by a client related to the Patient resource is processed here, and this is where all HTTP response codes come into play.
Author:
Christopher Zanoli, Undergraduate student - 270765@studenti.unimore.it

  • Method Details

    • getPatients

      @GET @Path("/") @Timed @Produces("application/json") public javax.ws.rs.core.Response getPatients(@Context javax.ws.rs.container.ContainerRequestContext req)
      This method allows managing and responding to a GET request from a client, who wants to obtain the list of registered patients.
      Parameters:
      req - Dropwizard maps the incoming request into an object, which can be used within our method
      Returns:
      1. If after loading the patient list from the specific data structure it is empty, then it responds with a 404 Not Found and an informational body serialized in JSON
      2. If, on the other hand, the list contains at least one patient, it responds with 200 OK + serialized payload in JSON
      3. If for any reason an exception is thrown, it is captured and the server responds with 500 Internal Server Error and an informational body serialized in JSON
      Since:
      1.0

    • getPatientById

      @GET @Path("/{patient_id}") @Timed @Produces("application/json") public javax.ws.rs.core.Response getPatientById(@Context javax.ws.rs.container.ContainerRequestContext req, @PathParam("patient_id") String patientId)
      This method allows managing and responding to a GET request from a client, who wants to obtain a particular patient through his patientId contained in the resource's URI.
      Parameters:
      req - Dropwizard maps the incoming request into an object, which can be used within our method
      patientId - it is a String representing the UUID of the patient, contained in the URI as @PathParam
      Returns:
      1. If the patietnID is not provided, then it responds with a 400 Bad Request and an informational body serialized in JSON
      2. If after loading the patient list from the specific data structure it is empty, then it responds with a 404 Not Found and an informational body serialized in JSON
      3. If, on the other hand, the list contains at least one patient, it responds with 200 OK + serialized payload in JSON
      4. If for any reason an exception is thrown, it is captured and the server responds with 500 Internal Server Error and an informational body serialized in JSON
      Since:
      1.0

    • createPatient

      @POST @Path("/") @Timed @Produces("application/json") @Consumes("application/json") public javax.ws.rs.core.Response createPatient(@Context javax.ws.rs.container.ContainerRequestContext req, @Context javax.ws.rs.core.UriInfo uriInfo, PatientCreationRequest patientCreationRequest)
      This method allows managing and responding to a POST request from a client, who wants to create a new patient.
      Parameters:
      req - Dropwizard maps the incoming request into an object, which can be used within our method
      uriInfo - it is the object made available by dropwizard that will allow us to reply with the absolute URI of the resource that has been created
      patientCreationRequest - it is the representation of the resource in relation to the DTO
      Returns:
      1. If the request is not valid according to the checks of isPatientCreationRequestValid method, then it responds with a 400 Bad Request and an informational body serialized in JSON
      2. After creating the patient through the InventoryDataManger, it responds with 201 Created + the Location Header with the absolute URI of the created patient
      3. If for any reason an exception is thrown, it is captured and the server responds with 500 Internal Server Error and an informational body serialized in JSON
      Since:
      1.0

    • updatePatient

      @PUT @Path("/{patient_id}") @Produces("application/json") @Consumes("application/json") public javax.ws.rs.core.Response updatePatient(@Context javax.ws.rs.container.ContainerRequestContext req, @PathParam("patient_id") String patientId, PatientUpdateRequest patientUpdateRequest)
      This method allows managing and responding to a PUT request from a client, who wants to update an already existing patient.
      Parameters:
      req - Dropwizard maps the incoming request into an object, which can be used within our method
      patientId - it is a String representing the UUID of the patient, contained in the URI as @PathParam
      patientUpdateRequest - it is the representation of the resource in relation to the DTO
      Returns:
      1. If the request is not valid according to the checks of isPatientUpdateRequestValid method or because patientIds mismatch between the body and the URI, then it responds with a 400 Bad Request and an informational body serialized in JSON
      2. After updating patient's data through the InventoryDataManger, it responds with 204 No Content
      3. If for any reason an exception is thrown, it is captured and the server responds with 500 Internal Server Error and an informational body serialized in JSON
      Since:
      1.0

    • deletePatient

      @DELETE @Path("/{patient_id}") @Produces("application/json") public javax.ws.rs.core.Response deletePatient(@Context javax.ws.rs.container.ContainerRequestContext req, @PathParam("patient_id") String patientId)
      This method allows managing and responding to a DELETE request from a client, who wants to delete an already existing patient.
      Parameters:
      req - Dropwizard maps the incoming request into an object, which can be used within our method
      patientId - it is a String representing the UUID of the patient, contained in the URI as @PathParam
      Returns:
      1. If the request is not valid then it responds with a 400 Bad Request and an informational body serialized in JSON
      2. After deleting patient's data through the InventoryDataManger, it responds with 204 No Content
      3. If for any reason an exception is thrown, it is captured and the server responds with 500 Internal Server Error and an informational body serialized in JSON
      Since:
      1.0
